In consideration of the ageing population of Japan, it is a relief to find that there are still young members of the workforce who are able to take the next step forward in small business ownership.

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a visual novel that deals with the startup and establishment of a small business in the local economy.
While not so much touching on the subject of financing and legal procedure associated with new entrepreneurship, NEKOPARA Vol. 1 does delve into the issues associated with human resource management particularly those of the interpersonal relationships between employees and employer. As with any SME (small and medium enterprises), delegation has long been an issue in the first few years of ownership. In fact, inefficient assignment of responsibilities is a major cause of business failure.

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 follows a young business owner in Japan as he works through the bumps and kinks faced by new business owners. It touches on subjects related to the securing and development of human resources which in turn leads to the promotion of organizational growth.

Nekopara is a beautiful love story between a man and his loyal cats showing him the value of family. It's the kind of light hearted love story that sincere, sensitive, gentle men would enjoy. Married men may want to sit this one out, but I would say it could make you more romantic and appreciative towards your spouse; clingy if you take it too far. And for any female gamers who may be interested in Nekopara: bless you for being able to step into a male protagonist's shoes and understanding.

I can not stress this enough: Nekopara is a heavenly fantasty that leaves you begging for more. Part of you will feel extremely satisfied after completion, but another part of you will be left longing for the warm embrace of a lover. IMO, these are very disirable feelings to have, and can only make you a better, sweeter person.

Nekopara Vol.1 is the first part of an upcoming series. And while the play time is only several hours, I think you may appreciate the low asking price. reviewText:
Nekopara is a cheerful slice-of-life story about you and the two catgirls who tagged along when you decide to leave the family business to pursue your career in cake making. Beautifully drawn and coupled with the animations and voice acting makes it one of the best presented VN's I've ever played.

The plot isn't really there plus around chapter 5, it starts to feel like a porno (as in 'my-cat-is-in-heat-and-the-only-way-to-help-her-is-to-get-it-on-and-not-read-the-pet-care-book-i-bought-a-few-chapters-ago'). However, the characters are interesting and the sprinkle of humor and cuteness through the game is enough to make you keep clicking forward. Also, small references.

Gameplay wise, it's linear,there are no branching choices at all. You can replay previous conversations (as in replaying the sound) but not 'reverse' back to a previous scene. No option to start at different chapters. You can hide the text box to view the scene better though.

Music is nice and comfy. Fits the cheerful theme of the game very well.

Overall, the game is like a cake. It's sweet and fluffy, but it's not very filling.

Extra notes:
- Twins don't mind sharing.
- It can be played with a controller, but once the game starts there is no button to access the menu.
- Vanilla is best

What has drawn me to NEKOPARA was, in the first moment, the art. Sayori's art looks so great, and I got really happy when I got notice that her circle, NEKO WORKs, was going to make a visual novel. NEKOPARA is a heartwarming story about a confectioner, Kashou, and the Nekos around him (though the story focuses on Chocolat and Vanilla, like on all of the NEKOPARA doujinshi by NEKO WORKs). It's a short and easy to read story that will have you giggle a lot, and feel warm inside too. I have to admit that Sekai Project's translation wasn't one of the best (as usual from them), but having played the game in both Japanese and English I feel safe saying that the translation doesn't kill the game's experience (and, the R-18 scene cuts can't be noticed at all).

If you're not looking for something with a serious plot and just have to take some weight off your routine, NEKOPARA is the right choice. If you plan on getting involved with a more complex and serious plot that will take up a lot of reading time, I suggest you go get something else, as this is NOT what you're looking for.

Not much ACTUALLY happens in terms of storyline. It's definitely more of a slice of life thing going on- though a majority of the text in the game is repeated over and over throughout the entire thing. Having completed NEKOPARA Vol. 1, I ask myself three questions:
1. What is the purpose of a visual novel game?
2. Are visual novel games for me?

Tender, heartwarming and strangely cathartic. This is the first VN I've ever played (and it will likely be the only one too) but this is a rather engaging sojourn into a world of genetically-engineered catgirls under domestic ownership.

As a visual novel the narrative is very simplistic and completely free of interactive elements but it's really, REALLY moe.

This is a story of the catgirls named Chocola and Vanilla, and their family; Kashou, his sister Shigure and their catgirls at home. Kashou moves from home to start a bakery with very mixed responses from his family. Upon unpacking, he finds his sister has left him some baggage to care for. And thus begins Kashou's paternal role and the coming of age of Chocola and Vanilla.

Outside of the myriads of slice of life elements played for the sake of being cute (I know a lot of people who are into that), Nekopara features several developmental tangents on behalf of the characters, the most evident being in the catgirls themselves. The playful pair reach several struggles with family and identity, being confused by human behavior, their roles at the bakery and even their feelings for their benefactor, Kashou. While not prize-winning material, Nekopara can and indeed does go the extra mile for playing the emotional strings and attempting to make empathetic characters. I cannot speak from experience but that's probably a lot more than can be said for other visual novels.

With that said, understand that this release has surprisingly little fanservice and much more focus on the feelings of the characters. PLEASE do not masturbate to this because that's a little harrowing to think of. If you do need more fap material I'd have to recommend a VN that rhymes with 'Sakura Spirit'. I've never played it but I do have friends who have, so check that out if you must.

Also, ignore the tags, the Steam version is very tame. Outside of a few crude remarks and censored nudity the release has little adult content.

reviewText:
First off, there is absolutely no interaction whatsoever, so set the text speed to something you're comfortable with and throw away your mouse, you'll never need it. Also the jiggly bits slider never seemed to change anything.

Lets start with the good parts. Catgirls are cute, bakeries are awesome, the uniforms for said bakery are pretty awesome, and the protagonists sister is adorable. The voice acting is about what you would expect from a title like this, nothing too special but its certainly not bad by any means. I was impressed with the E-Mote (think Live2D animations) system and animations that make the characters feel much more alive than regular old 2D could do, there are issues with this system that I'll bring up in the negative points.

I was extremely disappointed with the utter lack of interaction, no branches in story no choices, nothing. The story isn't that great and the characters don't change or grow much, but that can attributed to this being Volume 1 and also to this being less of an example of interactive fiction and more of a porn game with the porn removed. The scenario feels a bit contrived even allowing for suspension of disbelief about cat-people I never could quite find myself immersed. (I readily admit this is probably a personal failing.) The E-Mote system causes very noticeable stuttering when loading new characters into a scene; I was not the only one suffering from this problem, according to the forums.

On a more personal level, I didn't enjoy the protagonist getting together with multiple catgirls, especially given how many assets their designs reused, it just felt like two versions of the same character and I feel like the experience would have improved by just cutting one of the two characters or having two minor arcs dictated by a choice early on while leaving the one not selected as a background character.

All said, if you're excited for this title, I recommend getting the R18 version. This title is not worth the time without the explicit scenes in it and I don't even like that sort of thing.

reviewText:
Nekopara is a high quality kinetic novel (meaning no interactions, only reading) featuring catgirls and adult themes, although the Steam version is censored unless you apply some shenanigans to it (refer to this Community Hub link: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=370848130). The voice acting is in Japanese with subs for Japanese, English, and Chinese.

The art is extremely well done and fairly crisp. I played in a 1600x900 resolution which appears to be as high as it goes. Fullscreen will give it black borders as the game will maintain its aspect ratio to prevent stretched catgirls (very important). The level of quality that Nekopara has in terms of its art assets remains consistent throughout the entire experience with good coloring, shadowing, and light animations to help give the characters life such as head turning, blinking, breathing, and breast jiggling depend on how you use that slider.

I have no complaints with the music. It has tunes ranging from upbeat to laidback and brought me closer to my inner anime. The game comes with a music player that can Play, Stop Repeat, and Repeat All should you decide to just chill out. The opening song is pretty good.

Finally, the story seemed appropriate for what it was trying to do. It had its fair share of funny and “What is going on?” moments. The story follows Kashou and how he handles the two catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, coming into his life when he’s trying establish himself in the world as a baker. I don’t recommend thinking too hard about the rules that the world has regarding catgirls as those kind of discussions could lead to very strange places.

Voice acting seemed fine with tones that matched the dialogue. I really liked how they would say some of the verbs out loud. Rub, rub, for example. Or stare. That’s not something I’ve seen very often and adds a silly vibe to it.

Anyhoo, don’t purchase Nekopara for gameplay since there isn’t any. Your decision should be based on your interest in its story, the voice acting, the music, and the art.

reviewText:
NEKOPARA Vol.1 is the first in what I assume will be a series of short visual novels with the aim of making its readers melt with pleasure using a vast and varied array of female, feline, humanoid companions armed with cuteness and, well, catness. One of the first things I realized after starting the VN was that I was most definitely not the target audience for the title, which makes reviewing it a little difficult. While I personally didn’t enjoy the ride, it accomplishes everything it set out to do and does it reasonably well, so I’m going to attempt to cover both sides of the coin to give you an idea of whether this is a story that will appeal to you.

Minaduki Kashou has had enough of his family. Despite belonging to a long line of Japanese sweet makers, he would love nothing more than to open his own bakery, which is what he sets out to do. Just as he is about to complete his goal, however, he receives two unexpected guests in the form of his sister’s Catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, couriered to him along with the rest of his luggage. Catgirls are, as they sound, female cats in humanoid form, with all of the cuteness you might expect from the mix. If taught well, they can speak and operate almost as well as a normal person, so in this day and age many people have taken them on as “Catpanions”. They’re a massive responsibility, though, and Kashou just isn’t sure he can handle the two while opening his new store. However, the Catgirls aren’t going to give up without a fight and Kashou may soon find a place in his heart and his home for the young felines.

If any of that summary doesn’t sound like your sort of thing, it isn’t. NEKOPARA is a dedicated moege (game intended to be cute) catering to a specific audience and doesn’t aim to appeal to anyone outside of that field. It spends all its energy on the simple goal of displaying cute characters doing cute things, which it does well, so if that’s your cup of tea then it would probably be a fantastic experience. Even though I’m more of a fan of titles with heavy story components I still found myself smiling and laughing during the experience, and I have to acknowledge that the Catgirls are pretty darned cute, so you can be sure that it would be that much more enjoyable to someone who’s into the genre. Speaking of story, there’s really not much to NEKOPARA’s. It’s short, sharp, and doesn’t try to do a whole lot except at the very end in a chapter that seems rushed and anticlimactic. In short, if you don’t think that Catgirls doing cute things are enough to hold up a visual novel on their own, NEKOPARA isn’t for you.

Characterization is as shallow as you might expect it to be, with the heroines showcasing a single personality trait each in addition to the necessary devotion to their owner. That said, there are a range of both humans and Catgirls involved in the tale, with a greater role for the non-main heroines looking likely in future instalments, which is more than enough to accomplish what NEKOPARA sets out to do. I want to take a moment now to discuss the VN’s classification, because it will be important for some potential players. The Steam release that I played is “censored”, meaning that scenes considered R18 have been removed. The odd thing is that borderline nudity, explicit talk about sex and obviously skipped over sex scenes are all still included in the final package. Given that anyone purchasing the Steam version is going to get all that anyway, if you’re after a cute, all-ages moege then that’s just tough, and if you’re after that stuff then why the heck would you buy the Steam version?

One of NEKOPARA’s major selling points is its visuals and they’re worth all of the hype. Character design is great and sprites will talk, blink, tilt their heads, walk around the screen and more. Allowing the animations to complete was a reason in itself for letting each character finish talking rather than continuing on after reading each line, as it gave a depth to the characters that their personalities didn’t. While most of the dynamic sprite features run smoothly, I noticed a bit of lag when the sprites change to new positions or poses without using animation, which was jarring and a little disappointing considering the overall polish of the visual novel. The voice actors perform as well as is usual for Japanese productions and the BGM is also standard fare. One final feature that I find really cool is that you can choose to play in either English or Japanese, which makes the game a great resource for people wanting to practice either language.

Summary – NEKOPARA Vol.1 isn’t for me but for its target audience it could be a lot of fun. The technologically impressive visuals mix with cute, fun characters to deliver a solid moege. If it doesn’t sound like your sort of thing, however, it probably isn’t, as it lacks any sort of compelling story or character development. It’s worth noting that the Steam release isn’t really “all ages”, so if you’re after something innocent then you may want to look elsewhere also.

My Score: 6/10 – Average
Projected Score for Target Audience: 8/10 – Good

reviewText:
Like so many others, I had gotten this game expecting nothing more than an easy fap to nekos. That was seriously the ONLY expectation I even had coming in to the game was sexy catgirls. First thing I did, before I even opened it, was download the uncensored patch from online. Then I actually started playing...

See, the game (story really, there aren't any options) met my very basic expectations, and added substantially. It really made me a PART of the story, I really felt a connection with Chocola and Vanilla! I didn't think of them as the catgirls, I thought of them as MY catgirls. I know that's a looser thing to say, but I mean it.  The story is very touching, happy, and bubbly, and is told with EXCELLENT art and animation. Seriously, they characters were always moving (except in the rare, beautifully made still images), and that little element really added to the story.

Overall, this game was far more than anything I had expected.  I highly recommend it to anyone who likes nekos, and to be perfectly honest you can enjoy it very much even without the uncensored version; the story is DEFINATELY sound enough on it's own.  And as a bonus, there is definately going to be a Vol 2, based on the ending of this and the success of Vol 1.
